problem_text:
Find all integers n>1 such that the following hold simultaneously:
(i) n^4 divides 2^{18n}−1,
(ii) n^2 divides 5^{6n}−1,
(iii) n divides 7^{2n}−1.
Give a complete proof and the exact value of n.
solution_text:
Let n=∏ p^{e_p} with e_p≥1 for primes p|n. Since 2^{18n}−1 is odd, 2∤n.
Fix an odd prime p|n with e=e_p. Set t=ord_p(2). Then t|p−1, hence p∤t, and p|2^t−1. Condition (i) implies p|2^{18n}−1, so t|18n. Writing 18n=t·s yields 2^{18n}−1=(2^t)^s−1. By the simple-root lemma, v_p(2^t−1)=1. Lifting valuations for A^s−1 with p|A−1 and v_p(A−1)=1 gives v_p(2^{18n}−1)=1+v_p(s)=1+v_p(18n/t). Because p∤t and p≠3, we have v_p(18)=0, thus v_p(2^{18n}−1)=1+e. But (i) requires v_p(2^{18n}−1)≥4e, impossible for e≥1 since 1+e<4e. Therefore no odd prime p≥5 divides n.
Hence n=3^e with e≥1. For p=3, compute v_3(2^{18n}−1) using the even-exponent a+b variant by writing 2^{18n}−1=(2^9)^{2n}−1: since 3|(2^9+1) and 2n is even, v_3(2^{18n}−1)=v_3(2^9+1)+v_3(2n)=v_3(513)+v_3(n)=3+e. Condition (i) enforces 4e≤3+e, i.e., e≤1. With n>1, we obtain n=3.
Now verify (ii) and (iii) for n=3. For (ii), 5^{6n}−1=5^{18}−1 has even exponent and 3|5+1, so v_3(5^{18}−1)=v_3(5+1)+v_3(18)=v_3(6)+v_3(18)=1+2=3≥2, hence 3^2|5^{18}−1. For (iii), 7≡1 (mod 3) implies 3|7^{6}−1. Therefore n=3 satisfies all three conditions, and by the above exclusions, it is unique.

theorem_refs.name: LTE (a−b variant)
theorem_refs.statement: For odd prime p with p|a−b and p∤ab, v_p(a^n−b^n)=v_p(a−b)+v_p(n).
theorem_refs.source: Standard LTE; e.g., Wikipedia or olympiad compendia
theorem_refs.notes: Applied implicitly via lifting from A−1 to A^s−1.

theorem_refs.name: LTE (even-exponent a+b variant)
theorem_refs.statement: For odd prime p with p|a+b, p∤ab, and even n, v_p(a^n−b^n)=v_p(a+b)+v_p(n).

theorem_refs.name: Simple-root/Hensel lemma corollary
theorem_refs.statement: If t=ord_p(a) with p∤t, then v_p(a^t−1)=1.
theorem_refs.source: Hensel’s lemma for f(x)=x^t−1 and f'(a)≢0 mod p
theorem_refs.notes: Ensures the base valuation at the minimal period is exactly 1.

theorem_refs.name: Multiplicative order fact
theorem_refs.statement: For prime p∤a, ord_p(a) divides p−1.
